entry.title: Congrats to Mr. Jiwoo Song for passing his Ph.D. candidacy exam!

link.title: Congrats to Mr. Jiwoo Song for passing his Ph.D. candidacy exam!

entry.content:
Jiwoo started his journey with the APUS lab as a Master’s student and graduated in April 2024, and now he has passed the qualifying exam and become an official Ph.D. student. Good job!

PS: Rumor says he topped the candidacy exam.
entry.summary: Jiwoo started his journey with the APUS lab as a Master’s student and graduated in April 2024, and now he has passed the qualifying exam and become an official Ph.D. student. Good job!

entry.title: CAV seminar by Dr. Ashwin Renganathan from AERSP

link.title: CAV seminar by Dr. Ashwin Renganathan from AERSP

entry.content:
We hosted Dr. Ashwin Renganathan from AERSP/ICDS of PSU for a CAV talk via the AI/ML technical group. Dr. Renganathan is an expert in Bayesian decision theory.

Abstract Modern day engineering decision-making involves one or more computer simulation oracles of an engineered system which can be queried on-demand to learn the system response to control input. Querying simulation oracles, also called “computer experiments”, incur a non-trivial computational cost, which increases with the level of fidelity in the underlying models. For instance, a realistic computational aerodynamic simulation of an aircraft can cost several thousands of CPU hours to compute—anything more than a few dozens of such simulations is prohibitive. Therefore, a central goal of engineering decision-making is to optimally design computer experiments, to maximize the value of information extracted at minimal computational effort.

In this talk, we will address problems anchored in the decision-making triad namely: experiment design, uncertainty quantification, and numerical optimization. Specifically, using variants of Gaussian process surrogate models and a Bayesian decision theoretic framework, we will show that problems in the decision-making triad can be solved in a principled, theoretically sound and, yet, (computational) cost-effective manner. We will show demonstrations on applications in computational aerodynamics.
entry.summary: We hosted Dr. Ashwin Renganathan from AERSP/ICDS of PSU for a CAV talk via the AI/ML technical group. Dr. Renganathan is an expert in Bayesian decision theory.

entry.title: Congrats to Mr. Yin Yu for passing PhD defense!

link.title: Congrats to Mr. Yin Yu for passing PhD defense!

entry.content:
On 09/24/2024, Mr. Yin Yu successfully defended his PhD thesis, “Physics-Informed Data-Driven Modeling of Complex Networked Systems Through Graph Neural Networks”.

Yin’s work represents the data-driven end of our spectrum of research. Some of his research have been summarized in this post: Geometric Deep Learning for Dynamics on Graphs. His recent work further extends to methodology, theory, and application.

Yin is the first PhD student to graduate from our group. Congrats, Dr. Yu!
entry.summary: On 09/24/2024, Mr. Yin Yu successfully defended his PhD thesis, “Physics-Informed Data-Driven Modeling of Complex Networked Systems Through Graph Neural Networks”.

entry.title: Welcome New Lab Member – Mr. Bayu Prasetyo

link.title: Welcome New Lab Member – Mr. Bayu Prasetyo

entry.content: Mr. Bayu Prasetyo graduated from Penn State in 2024 with an Honors Thesis: “Leveraging Koopman Operator Theory to Design a Drone Controller for Operation in Nonlinear Flight Conditions”. He continued to work with us, and co-advisor Dr. Junyi Geng, on quadcopter control using Koopman dynamics.

entry.title: Welcome New Lab Member – Mr. Subarna Pudasaini

link.title: Welcome New Lab Member – Mr. Subarna Pudasaini

entry.content: Mr. Subarna Pudasaini obtained a B.E. in Aerospace Engineering from Tribhuvan University (TU), Nepal, in 2023. Now he joins Penn State with a research topic on the control co-design of morphing aerial vehicles.

entry.title: Learning Bilinear Dynamics of Networked Systems

link.title: Learning Bilinear Dynamics of Networked Systems

entry.content:
Networked systems, i.e., the systems that involve many interacting dynamical components, are universal in engineering; an example is the energy system of an electrified aircraft. Obtaining a dynamic model from the data of such a system has two challenges: (1) the data is unstructured (defined on graph) - this causes difficulties in model representation, and (2) the system is typically stiff due to multiple timescales - this causes difficulties in learning the dynamics.

To overcome the above challenges, in our recent ArXiv manuscript, we developed a weak Latent Dynamics Model (wLDM) for learning possibly stiff nonlinear dynamics with control, and extended the wLDM framework to develop weak Graph Koopman Bilinear Form (wGKBF) model, which integrates geometric deep learning and Koopman theory to learn latent space dynamics for networked systems.

The work is done jointly with Dr. Herschel Pangborn from Mechanical Engineering at Penn State.

(Figure shows effectiveness of wGKBF model in comparison to the standard biDMD algorithm for an electrified aircraft system.)
entry.summary: Networked systems, i.e., the systems that involve many interacting dynamical components, are universal in engineering; an example is the energy system of an electrified aircraft. Obtaining a dynamic model from the data of such a system has two challenges: (1) the data is unstructured (defined on graph) - this causes difficulties in model representation, and (2) the system is typically stiff due to multiple timescales - this causes difficulties in learning the dynamics.

entry.title: Downscaling Unstructured Spatiotemporal Data
entry.content:
The resolution-coverage dilemma is a common challenge in climate research, where the coverage is inversely proportional to the resolution at the same cost. Downscaling is a technique to overcome the dilemma by fusing spatiotemporal data of different resolutions. Downscaling has been done for spatially continuous datasets, such as climate simulation data, but it remains a challenge to fuse unstructured distributed data, such as weather station measurements.

In our recent work, we tackle the downscaling involving a mixture of structured and unstructured data via a graph neural network (GNN) framework, and applied the framework to a street-level temperature estimation problem. Furthermore, we conducted in-depth analysis of feature importance to enhance the model interpretability; sensitivity of features are shown in figure below. Our findings highlight GNN’s high potential in capturing the complex dynamics between urban elements and their impacts on microclimate, thus offering valuable insights for comprehensive urban data collection and urban climate modeling in general.

The work is done jointly with Dr. Ashish Sharma and Dr. Peiyuan Li from UIUC/DPI.
entry.summary: The resolution-coverage dilemma is a common challenge in climate research, where the coverage is inversely proportional to the resolution at the same cost. Downscaling is a technique to overcome the dilemma by fusing spatiotemporal data of different resolutions. Downscaling has been done for spatially continuous datasets, such as climate simulation data, but it remains a challenge to fuse unstructured distributed data, such as weather station measurements.

entry.title: Learning Coarse-Grained Dynamics on Graph
entry.content:
“Heterogeneous networked dynamical systems with time-varying topologies” are universally seen in science and engineering - classical examples include power grids, molecule dynamics, and computational mechanics. For the data-driven modeling of such systems, the brutal force approach is to use a time series model with a sufficiently deep graph neural network (GNN) with sufficiently long time-delay embedding (TDE) of past information.

To elucidate when and how such approach works, in our recent ArXiv manuscript, we systematically developed coarse-grained reduced-order models for networked dynamical systems. Using the Mori-Zwanzig formalism, we quantify the impact of coarse-graining on the strength and distribution of interactions, and the required TDE length; subsequently we use this knowledge to rigorously design GNN architectures accordingly. The approach is demonstrated on an academic Kuramoto example and a realistic power grid problem.

The work is done jointly with Dr. John Harlim from Math & Meteorology and Dr. Yan Li from EECS at Penn State.
entry.summary: “Heterogeneous networked dynamical systems with time-varying topologies” are universally seen in science and engineering - classical examples include power grids, molecule dynamics, and computational mechanics. For the data-driven modeling of such systems, the brutal force approach is to use a time series model with a sufficiently deep graph neural network (GNN) with sufficiently long time-delay embedding (TDE) of past information.

entry.title: Modularized Bilinear Koopman Operator for Modeling and Predicting Transients of Microgrids

link.title: Modularized Bilinear Koopman Operator for Modeling and Predicting Transients of Microgrids

entry.content:
We just published an article in IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid, with the application of the so-called Koopman Bilinear Form (KBF) to networked system with inputs, such as the power grid. Particularly, we (1) derive and incorporate conditions in KBF model to enforce SO(2) symmetry for accurate and long-term predictions, (2) make KBF model modularized to allow prediction in reconfigurable scenarios without retraining the model.

The work is done jointly with Dr. Yan Li from Penn State EECS. It is the published version of our prior arXiv paper here.
entry.summary: We just published an article in IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid, with the application of the so-called Koopman Bilinear Form (KBF) to networked system with inputs, such as the power grid. Particularly, we (1) derive and incorporate conditions in KBF model to enforce SO(2) symmetry for accurate and long-term predictions, (2) make KBF model modularized to allow prediction in reconfigurable scenarios without retraining the model.

entry.title: Computational Science Minor Program
entry.content:
We recently took the responsibility in the supervision of the Computational Science Minor program offered by Penn State Aerospace Engineering.

This minor program provides the necessary skills to use computers to study and solve scientific, engineering and data-centric problems across a wide range of disciplines. It was developed with numerical methods and onboard computing in mind back in the early 2000s, and now it evolves to encompass topics such as machine learning and artificial intelligence.

If you are interested, more details are here.
entry.summary: We recently took the responsibility in the supervision of the Computational Science Minor program offered by Penn State Aerospace Engineering.
